To me, blood transfusions are big business for a large bloated bureacracy that is doing everything it can to maintain itself and grow. 

To me, shortages of blood lead to far less blood-intensive therapies which could eventually lead to eliminating the barbaric practice altogether. 

I feel the same way about organ transplants, but I recognize that I have no further use for my organs when I'm dead, and that technology has not advanced to the point where these patients have any other choice. I believe the day will come when the very idea of a transplanted organ or blood from another human being (that is not an identical clone of oneself) will be abhorrent.

Organ transplants have no alternative. But with blood I knew in high-school, more than twenty years ago, that there were widely available alternatives that were routinely ignored because of the huge blood business and its marketing clout. 

The shortages are driving doctor's to alternatives, and that is reducing shortages. Simple economics. Since I'd rather hurry along the long-term solution and don't need the short-term gratification of "doing something charitable" through the Red Ripoff, I don't donate blood.

Why all that matters in this world is education. It's the key. The key to SO MUCH:

http://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/17/business/17scene.html?ex=1337054400&en=f9d301d977378b71&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss

I personally cannot understand for the life of me how anyone can consider anything other than an education to be a status symbol. How can anyone idolize a sub-par singer with absurd hair over the smartest guy in their class? 

But they do. And they're getting exactly what they deserve (the idolizers and the smartest guy in the class). 

Next time you see a kid, before you tell them how good they look, before you tell them how cool their toy is, before you ask them what they got for their birthday or whether they had fun at Disneyworld or who their favourite athlete is, ask them HOW THEIR DAY AT SCHOOL WAS. Put it FIRST. Every time. Jeeze.

Breakdown: Young smart-ass in office makes GTA-style comment (in jest) about a gun. Co-worker overhears and has a hissy fit. Young smart-ass is fired. Case closed. Only it isn't. Young smart-ass is a webcomic author. He makes a comic about how silly the whole thing is. Pronto, the cops come and tell him he's "borderline" on being charged as a terrorist.

Now our young smart-ass is not sure he can even fly to San Francisco without problems. He's given up buying a target-practice gun since he figures he can't pass the background check now.

Notice his crime: Speaking of hypothetical violence in an office cubicle, getting fired, then making a webcomic about it and putting it online. 

Note: Kids talk like this all the time. It's a GTA thing.

Some crime huh?

The Bartle Test  



Based on your answers, you are ESAK.
Breakdown: Achiever 40.00%, Explorer 80.00%, Killer 13.33%, Socializer 66.67%

ESAK players often see the game world as a great stage, full of things to see and people to meet. They love teaming up with people to get to the hard-to-see places, and they relish unique experiences.



The Bartle Test was originally designed for players of MUDs (multi-user dungeons) but continues to have applicability to virtual worlds of all kinds--especially MMORPGs. The test attempts to measure a player based on what they enjoy most about a game, based on four axes:
The Four Bartle Catagories

  • People with high Achiever scores tend to prefer collecting points, levels, treasure and accomplishments that set them apart from other players--or simply present challenges.
  • People with high Explorer scores tend to enjoy finding all of the unique areas of the world, often enjoying the immersion of the experience. Finding a place with unique monsters and seeing what those monsters do is usually more fun for an Explorer than defeating the monsters themselves.
  • People with high Killer scores prefer the player-versus-player aspect of any game more than anything offered by the environment. They often relish the adrenaline and challenge of pitting themselves against real players.
  • People with high Socializer scores enjoy interacting with other people, forming organizations, and finding cooperative solutions to the challenges within the virtual world.




Acknowledgements: Thank you to Dr. Richard Bartle for the original design of this test, as well as Erwin Andreasen for maintaining the original test-taking database for many years.

Could NOT agree more.

The USPS has got to go.

I figure about once every three months I notice that I have not received a bill or statement that I needed and nearly miss a payment. It happens so frequently that it can only be described as systemic. I have complained. I was told that "test" letters would be coming to our house by mails so they could see if things were working. 

Nothing has happened, and the problem continues. 

The answer is to start over with private mail. I'd love to do the same for mulitple other federal agencies, but let's start with the USPS.

The other answer I've already implemented: 99% of my bills and financial transactions are done electronically anyway. I only have one or two dinosaur companies that don't offer eBills. I don't even receive credit card offers anymore, since I shut that off at the source... credit rating agencies. I also eliminated most of my other junk mail by opting out with the direct mail organization (forget the name). Anything urgent always goes through FedEx, not matter the cost, on general principle.

I guess that means that if I can't fix the USPS, if they won't fix themselves, and if we can't privatize it, at least we can cut off it's oxygen by not using it.

These are the same question, mathematically. If you can solve one you can solve the other. It just looks more complicated.

The only thing in the Chinese version that is different is the proof. 

http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23393742-details/One+of+these+is+a+test+sat+by+Chinese+students.++The+other+is+the+British+version.+(No+prizes+for+guessing+which)/article.do

But yeah, you shouldn't be able to stop taking math and still go on to university and expect to be a chemist. It isn't the math itself that matters, it's the critical thinking skills. Math is just a very good avenue to teach this ability to think. Math also makes it easy to measure development in critical thinking skills. It's much harder to test a student's ability to think using writing skills or geography.

Kids aren't dropping out of math because "they're not good at math". They're dropping out of math because they're not good at thinking. We shouldn't be letting them stop learning to think until they're out of school and out from under our control. All we get by letting students "prefer" something that is not math-related is stupid students. 

Exception: Certain people I know - Conn in particular - can think critically and don't like math. I consider him the exception. If we had other means to demonstrate critical thinking skills other than math, I'd have no complaint. But we don't. So I think we should insist on students taking more math. Sorry Conn.

You are on a slippery slope. Your top judicial body is acting like the rest of your elected representatives. 

When the top court of the country makes a decision, and the play-by-play breaks down on political lines with NO MENTION of the constitutional merits of the case or decision, you are all doomed. The central concept of your country is failing. 

Some may argue that it has been failing for a long while. Some may say the slide is well underway. Some may say it's always been this way and it's worked out OK. But for this observer this marks a major milestone. Your high court should not be a political body. Up to now SCOTUS has (to my mind) upheld the highest law of the land against the hopes of the political extremists. 

And now they've just acted like politicians and my fears have been realized.  

http://edition.cnn.com/2007/LAW/04/18/scotus.abortion/index.html

How long before the constitutionality of their decisions is flagrantly ignored while they follow their assigned political orders? How long before your final recourse, your final protection from elected thugs is gone? 

The deck has been stacked, the slide has begun.

We'd probably get along just fine.

I found this blog by economist Greg Mankiw at Harvard and I really like reading it.

He posted a parable about taxes today that I have seen before and that really reasonates with me. 

Essentially it's about the wrong-headedness of people's attitudes about the rich and the poor and the question of who pays taxes and who should get tax breaks when tax rates are reduced. The moral of the story is that the rich guy decides to leave and his tax money disappears.

I posted a comment a few minutes ago. 

Anonymous said...

Another problem with this parable (which I have seen before in difference forms) is that it doesn't distinguish between the wealthy and those who are just high-earners.

My wife and I are not wealthy. When we married 5.5 years ago we had a net worth of zero. She finished school and got a new job, and one year we realized we were in the top 5% of tax filers according to the IRS. It seemed unbelievable. Our net worth has reached 6 figures this year and we are concentrating on continuing that trend. I went back to school to pursue a PhD in Physics because I am not satisfied and want to accomplish more.

The question is: Regardless of the "wealthy" who "all inherited it" we have to consider whether we can continue to make this kind of forward progress here in the USA. If taxes are increased at our expense and the benefits are minimal or if - even worse - the economic climate actually deteriorates in this country... we will have to leave. We currently pay more in taxes than three of my close friends combined earn in a year. Where will they get their public services if my wife and I leave? We have little wealth to take with us, we have only our technical skill, experience, and productivity.

If boomers insist on increasing taxes to fund retirements they should've funded themselves like we are, if the poor continue to increase in number and demand a larger share of our earnings when we were both once poor just like them, if the government continues to squander tax money inefficiently and grow in size to no benefit to us, then we will act rationally and leave.

The parable, for wage earners moreso than for the "already rich" is very valid. Take it from a couple of highly educated young people who are not rich but are determined to work hard and become rich: We will leave and pay taxes to a country that provides us with value for our money. There are other countries that are being considerably more rational about many things these days than the US. There is no guarantee that this country will automatically win the economy game and be the richest and best forever, certainly not the way it's been going lately.

I never make mistakes like this.

Gah, what is wrong with me!?

Rather than pollute Bill's blog entry with snarky comments I thought I'd post this here instead.

I am honestly beginning to think that if podcasts and other new media are going to become widespread, the same rules that apply to television shows should apply to them. 

In other words, I think any podcast with a commercial element should have a downloadable transcript. If you have advertising on your web site that can result in revenue, the rule should apply. Television shows make money through advertising and they have to have closed captioning by law.

I used to just shrug off the inaccessibility of this new media. It wasn't very prevalent and I considered much of it to be amateur trash (like most of YouTube is but I assume Bill's is not). Unfortunately as more of the things I care about go to this format and as less is done as prose I'm being left behind and it's upsetting. I am a big gamer fan, and all the entertainment action in that genre is in podcasts. I'm a fan of Battlestar Galactica and all their "extra content" online has no captioning. Even the snippets they show after the show are uncaptioned. I know everyone in television is only captioning because the federal government forced them to. I guess I thought my generation was less likely to be so ignorant and uncaring, but apparently not. So instead of waiting to see what happens I'm getting angry instead.

I'm trying to balance my frustration with the cognizance that regulation will interfere with this kind of new, free, expression. I know a podcast is pretty easy to do. Turn on the mike, talk, upload, done. Some people are editing, some are working harder at it, some are even working from scripts. Somewhere in that progression from rank amateur to commercial media I think the captioning rules should be applied. In particular when people like Scott Kurtz are making a living off the new media, I feel I can be a bit more demanding. The only difference between his "series" and an old-style TV show is the transmission medium. Everything else is exactly the same, so I feel the rules should apply. 

If people won't voluntarily make their commercial media accessible to me then I feel justified in forcing them to do so legally. I know this will never happen but I needed to vent.

Sometimes the NOTW guy bugs me.

He scoffs at the effort that went into this solution to an obscure, seemingly pointless, mathematical problem. I can usually relate but in this particular case I know a bit about why it matters.

First of all, solving this kind of problem in this way provides a deep education to any graduate students associated with the work. If I never did a math problem that wasn't earth-shatteringly-important I'd never do homework.

Secondly, the techniques developed to do this kind of thing usually result in new technologies that DO have wide-ranging practical application. This is the usual argument in favour of things like NASA, btw.

Finally, there are a number of areas of physics and mathematics that are lacking in solutions that resemble this kind of problem. If someone needs to know, really NEEDS to be sure, that something is or is not possible, this result may be applicable and thus important. 

Just because "yr editor" isn't a mathematician or interested in math doesn't mean he should just mindlessly denigrate people who are working on this kind of thing. When he denigrates a politician that is full of shit or a nutcase that has a collection of 17 million paperclips, each with an unique name, then I agree. But not in this case.

I don't care how much people like football more than algebra. If the school is cutting funding for academic programs but getting new artificial turf for its football field, something is seriously, seriously wrong. 

I've heard all the arguments in favour of athletics as a way to get kids into college, to stay in high-school, to keep their grades up, and I reject all of them. There's something fundamentally wrong if students simply don't understand the importance of their own education and no amount of bullshit ra-ra-ra football is going to change that.

Kid hangs himself imitating Saddam's execution after seeing it on TV. 

Parents: "They shouldn't be able to put that on TV."

Uh-huh. Obviously what we need to prevent this is to stop a barely-free press from freely bringing us major world news. No mention of how a 10-year-old could hang himself in a house full of kids being watched by their uncle. Just the uncle's claim that it's TV's fault. 

At least the article itself had a quote stating the obvious: Don't let 10-year-old kids watch violent stuff on television, or if they see it, discuss it with them so they know to separate reality from imagination. 

I won't claim this isn't a tragedy, because my heart goes out to the kid's mother. But I will say that my fellow-feeling was mostly ruined by the idiodic comments of the family trying to shift the blame. 

I may be overly strict with my kid. (Nah. That's not true. I WILL be overly strict.) Hopefully nothing like this ever happens to us. If it does, I hope I have the sense to recognize my own culpability.

I got this link from News of the Weird's blog again. Parents of a severely disabled girl are deliberately stunting her growth so she'll be easier to pick up and care for.

Initial reaction: "OMFG stop them!".

Reasoned reaction after reading the article: "That may very well be the best choice."

I highly doubt the majority of readers or people in general (when they find out about it) will ever get to the "reasoned" point. This will be interesting to watch though.

I am a big web comic fan, particularly web comics about games. I came across this post by Kurtz referencing this post by Kris on the "death of politeness".

Essentially the claim is that the internet, in particular the anonymity of the internet, has caused us all to become rude nitpickers. Self-professed "experts" on everything and anything. The posters long for the "good old days," pre-internet, when you showed someone your work of art and everyone was polite and said "oh that is very good" instead of sniping at you behind an anonymous user name.

Leaving aside completely my feeling that we are far, far too "polite" in person and never provide any meaningful feedback to people for fear of hurting the feelings anyway, I think these two guys have completely missed the point. I didn't feel like this is any less "polite" than people are when they're in their anonymous cars driving down the highway. People are just as rude there. That isn't the problem.

To me the problem is there are far too many people who really do think they are experts on everything. They really do want to post and to appear as though they know enough to nitpick about something they have just seen or read. We really are in an age where just about everyone that goes to a movie thinks they could've done better than the actual creators of the movie. 

I am certainly guilty of this. I consume a large number of theatrical plays every year. I am a critic. I will tell Jaime at length the things I think worked and didn't work. I took a theatre class last semester and wrote four critiques of plays that all got 100% grades. Many, many of my fellow students did far worse. Some never even bothered actually going to plays, they lied or faked it. Many of the papers were so poor it was obvious the writers had no comprehension of theatre as art, that they didn't understand any kind of artisitic complexity in any kind of performance at all.

But... I feel completely certain that if you went through the online posts on online forums of things each student was individually interested in, such as games, music, MySpace, LJ, etc., etc., and analyzed how many places they posted as though they were qualified to make expert critiques of the subject, you'd find many, if not most, were convinced in their own abilities to do so. They would post as though they were experts, some politely, some rudely, some with horrific grammer or slang or obscenities or whatever, and they'd probably tell you in-person that they "were really good" at whatever their personal interest was.

Realistically, as evidenced by their inability to observe and write any kind of reasonable critique of a play, the truth is they're actually completely incapable of judging most of what they consume culturally in any way.

I think the reason they fool themselves in this way is because it's the only way they can build an internal image of themselves that is not completely embarrassing. They can't go through life with the truth that they are actually not very smart and actually don't know much about anything, actually don't know how to DO anything at all. They work in mindless jobs that are mostly image, or mostly make-work, and they go through school taking place-holder classes and avoiding anything difficult. If they really analyzed what they thought they were experts in, their self-image would crumble. I have taken non-science classes and observed otherwise stupid students who belligerently claim to be experts on many things, more expert than I am on things I have studied at length for years, or have done professionally for years. I'm talking about 18-year-old college freshmen arguing with me about software development, firmly convinced they know more than anyone else in the class on the subject. I have taken science classes and seen the students whose parents have told them how smart they are for 20 years, who can't do simple arithmetic and have no real thinking skills, but are experts in something-or-other (check out my cool iPod mix!) to maintain an image. I've seen them swagger up to their non-science friends and accept the adulation from marginally more-stupid people like they are kings or queens, while carrying a math exam in their backpack with a failing grade on it.

The lack of politeness is not new. The swagger of self-professed experts covering up their true stupidity is not new. All the internet has done is provide a new, far easier avenue for this to reach a wider audience. 

If anything, I think we should be telling more of these people to their faces what we really think of them. Maybe if we told them earlier in their lives how little they knew, or how poorly they were doing, they'd actually go out and work on becoming real experts instead of just building these fantasy images of themselves instead. But... that would be pretty impolite, I guess. Wouldn't want to be impolite to people, oh no.

You gotta love this.

http://www.detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061130/OPINION01/611300306/1008

If politicians in Michigan think they have the authority to control the lives of their citizens in this way, what else do they think they are allowed to tell us to do? 

I am watching this kind of thing very carefully. Most Americans may have themselves convinced that their country is the best in the world, which is simply not true. Mostly they believe that their political system is perfect and invincible, but this kind of thing proves otherwise. Eventually the US Supreme Court will be stacked sufficiently well that they will cease to protect the citizens from violations of the constitution. Eventually America will be sufficiently un-free that multiple other countries will be safer to live in, and probably will have lower taxes as well. When that happens we're going to have to consider leaving. I stayed here for love. I am financially successful working here and reasonably free. But the trajectory of this country is definitely negative in both regards. The differential between Canada, Britain, Australia and the US in terms of the economy, taxes and freedoms is closing rapidly and it won't be long before the US is clearly much worse. Then it'll be time to move on. 

I have zero confidence that the people of this country can get their act together and clean it up. 

Hopefully PhD will make it easier to go when we need to.

http://edition.cnn.com/2006/US/10/06/college.protesters/index.html

I would be the first person to jump up and shout "no fair" when I see discrimination against the deaf and hard-of-hearing. I have a tattoo specifically to remind me to do so every morning when I look in the mirror.

But the deaf community has typically been a complete waste of my time. They claim to speak for the deaf and hard-of-hearing, and yet they are often more hostile and intolerant than the "enemy" they are purportedly fighting. 

So, while I want to do something about being able to fly and understand better what is happening at the gate and on board, and while I spend time with my company's disability council and task force, the deaf are busy trying to get rid of a deaf person that isn't "deaf enough" to be the president of their college. This woman - born deaf - chose to try to operate in the mainstream instead of barricading herself away from the public. So the deaf students in her school refuse to accept her as president. She's "deaf-er" than I am, now that I have an implant. Oh, and in France, the deaf community has parties where deaf kids smash their implants in protest of being forcibly "integrated" into the mainstream. 

Gee thanks. Where would I ever be without the help of these heroic deaf groups, eh? 

/eyeroll

So... I'm drunk on my recent technolust sating.

Jaime and I wanted a better digital camera for when the baby comes. But I didn't want a basic point-and-shoot, I wanted something better. I also dislike how long a typical digital camera takes to shoot a photo. I also REALLY like macro shots, which means I wanted a camera I could switch lenses on (at least eventually).

So this is what we bought. A Nikon D50 with the 18-55mm DX lens. We got both as a kit (factory demo) on eBay for just under $600 including shipping. The memory card (1GB SD) was only another $16 at Microcenter.

We get some fantastic photos. We've started a kinda-sorta album thingie. The actual website is our own domain. www.CJHImages.com It'll ask for a password. You should all know my last name, but if you don't, it's 'henderson'.

The speed of the camera is amazing. You pull the trigger, and just like the old 35mm film SLRs, bam!, you got the shot. It's fantastic. If you're just pulling the trigger haphazardly and trying to get a shot (I've probably shot 750 photos since I got the camera last night) it keeps up no problem. Just bam, bam, bam, shot after shot. SOOO much better than a point-and-shoot. I'm ecstatic about the camera, no exaggeration.

Comments on the photos would be appreciated (put them here on LJ). It was my first try. Lots of shots in the dark with the flash turned off.

Oh! And if you like Zenfolio, get the referrer number from me so we both save $5 when you buy your first year. I think it's a great site and a great deal. Excuse my sales pitch. *grin*

I give you  ONE sentence from my reading assignment in Philosophy this week.

Yes. ONE.

For since something must needs have been from eternity; as hath been already proved, and is granted on all hands: either there has always existed one unchangeable and independent Being, from which all other beings that are or ever were in the universe, have received their original; or else there has been an infinite succession of changeable and dependent beings, produced one from another in an endless progression, without any original cause at all: which latter supposition is so very absurd, that tho' all atheism must in its account of most things (as shall be shown hereafter) terminate in it, yet I think very few atheists ever were so weak as openly and directly to defend it.
